newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean stocks close up, Tae Sung rumours ignored.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean stocks close up, Tae Sung rumours ignored.

text.p: South Korean stocks closed higher in Saturday's half-day session on buying led by foreigners and off-shore funds, brokers said.
Investors ignored rumours that Tae Sung Machinery and Construction Co had defaulted on debt payments. Trading in Tae Sung shares has been suspended.
The composite index closed up 8.46 points, or 1.15 percent, at 746.89 after briefly dropping into negative territory.
"Tae Sung rumours were ignored because hardships at the company had already been circulating and reflected," said Koh Kyung-bae of Hyundai Securities.
The Korea Stock Exchange said Tae Sung was also rumoured to be planning to apply for court receivership. Officials at the company were not immediately available for comment.
Brokers said shares in securities firms and big-name construction firms rose on buying by foreigners and off-shore funds managed by local investment firms.
The sub-index for securities firms was up 4.83 percent or 60.31 points to 1,307.94 points.
Brokers said Friday's release of current account deficit figures also boosted sentiment. The deficit narrowed to $1.04 billion in May from a $1.59 billion shortfall a year earlier.
Brokers saw the market moving in a range between 720 and 760 points next week, with investors focusing on firms perceived to have enjoyed big earnings growth in the half-year to June.
"There will be no big rises or falls next week, but the market will instead move in a boxed range," said Koh Soon-shik of LG Securities.
September index futures closed up 1.4 points at 80.70 while the underlying KOSPI-200 index ended up 1.2 points at 77.53.
